text: And he says that this advice is backed up by decades of research. A decade is a period of 10 years and when we say decades,it’s a general term for many years, at least 20. Let’s hear that advice again from Dr Grandner.

speaker: counter-intuitivedecades
text: And it sounds counter-intuitive, but trust me I’ve got decades of data behind this statement: If you cannot sleep, get out of bed.

speaker: Neil
text: So why is getting out of bed good advice? Here’s the explanation from Dr Grandner.

speaker: dilutedtossing and turningchronicinsomnia
text: When you’re in bed and you’re not asleep and you do that over, and over, and over again for extended periods of time, the ability of the bed to put you to sleep starts getting diluted. Not only that, it starts getting replaced by thinking, and tossing and turning, and worrying, and doing all these things. When you’re not asleep, get out of bed. This is probably one of the most effective ways to prevent chronic insomnia. It’s also one of the really effective ways to treat it. It won’t work 100% of the time, but it will actually work more than most people think.

speaker: dilutes
text: We normally sleep in beds. Beds are designed to make it easy to sleep, but if we can’t sleep, that makes the bed’s impact weaker. As Dr Grandner says, 'it dilutes the power of the bed to help us sleep'.

speaker: dilute
text: When you dilute something, you make it weaker. For example, you can dilute the strength of a strong fruit juice by adding water to it.

speaker: tossing and turning
text: So if we stay in bed, tossing and turning, which is the expression we use to describe moving around in the bed trying to get to sleep, we begin to think of the bed as place where we don’t sleep rather than as a place where we do sleep. So, get out of bed to break the connection.

speaker: chronicinsomniaChronic
text: This he says is a positive way to approach chronic insomnia. Chronic is an adjective that is used to describe conditions that are long-lasting. So we’re not talking here about occasionally not being able to get to sleep, but a condition where it happens every night.

text: Well when I can’t sleep, I get up and read trivia! And now it’s time for the vocabulary. Today our topic has been insomnia.

speaker: toss and turn
text: This is the word for the condition of not being able to sleep. And something that people do when they are trying to sleep is toss and turn in bed.

speaker: counter-intuitive
text: The opposite of what seems logical or obvious is counter-intuitive. It goes against what you might expect. So if you can’t sleep, get out of bed.

speaker: dilutedto dilute
text: Our next word is diluted. This is from the verb to dilute which means 'to make something less strong'.

speaker: chronicchronic insomnia
text: And finally there was the adjective chronic. This is an expression for a medical condition that is long-lasting. So someone who has chronic insomnia regularly has difficulty getting enough sleep. It’s not just something that happens now and again.
